label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, December 1, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, regarding the discrepancies between the censorship of their letters and what the media is reporting, his tour around a submarine, and the cooking he and Morris do with canned goods. Sidney continues in his letter to recount his end of the story of their difficulties trying to connect on a phone call and his irritation at being told they have to move offices again.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
December 1, 1942
Gertie Darling,
In order that you may check and see whether you
have received all my letters I will list the dates on which they
were written below. On the first of every month I will send you
a similiar list for the previous month.
November 1,3,5,7,10,12,14, 18,20,28. The long
jump between the 20th. and 28th was when Morris was ill and I was
so busy. He is back at the office now and it really feels as
if I am on vacation there is so little to do. He returned yesterday
morning and after we had finished the accumalation of the weekend
I was able to read some of the reports that I had tossed into a
big basket. They were very interesting but could not touch
Life Magazines pictures and story of Guadalcanal. We almost died
in the office when we saw them as we have been sending the same
type of thing out as["]most secret.["]It really kills me
to see how everything has to be so secret with us while the rest of t
the world is reading about it in the newspapers and magazines.
Well this is the third time today that I have ripped this
letter out and done somethi g else. However here I am back again
with the news that it is rainXing cats and dggs and has been
since early last night. When we came this mornirg it was necessary
to take twice as long as the water in the streets was up to our hubs
in many cases, and the c rs were plowing through it like battleships.
The navy yard becomes a sea of mud and everyoneis filthy by the end of
a day.
Went on board a submarine thism rning and was fascinated.
[End Page 1]
2
never in my life have I seen so many gadjets, wheels and dials.
all I could think about was what Morris and Sammy Trincher could do
to mechanism like that during the ocurse of an evenning. It would be
like thetimethey took your camera apart or laid the stair c rpet.
Last night was the scene of a wonderful dinner. We have
a cook book, a very good one tooo de ling only with canned foods
as the writer wisely says in the beggining that ["]no man has the time
to shell peas, slice c rrots or do all the foolish things that women
think are neces ary to in order to prepare a simple dinner.["]
First we had chicken soup, as they call it in the south, "fresh out of
the can.["]Other things["]fresh out of the can["]were sweet potaotes,
green peas, apple sauce, and ["]b rds eye["]fish. The latter was marvellous
and although the smell of fish clung to bur hands all evening[,]
it tasted very good. I think however we should have thawed it out
before cooking as it cooked quite so[L]id and I do not believe ever beca[-]
me warm, however Morris said this was alright as he has often had
cold fish with myannoise and this is robably how they cook it.
I never thought of thatbefore andthing it isa very good idea.
One of our men came down["]from under["]. He had left us
several weeks ago. I hardly recognized him he was so thin. Did not
have a chance to talk as he just stopped at my desk, but he is returning
to the states and of course isvery happy about it. He was very
funnny about his job as he was the chief engineer on a ship, and
swears he does not know one end of an engine from another. Asa
result he use to just fish over the sides until a gun went off and then.
would dive belwo and show great interestin the engine room.
I had intended to ask him to see you if he wenc to Washington but he
said there was nto a chance of his going there so did not bother
to send any messages.
[End Page 2]
3
It was great fun talking to you over the telephone, and such a 
wonderful suprise. The first thing I knew about it was when I
came hme with Morris at four oclock to hear the telephone ringing.
I debated whtether to answerit or not as I thought it might be some
man wanting to come out for the eveing and we di[d] not want to see
anyone. Finally I picked up the receiver and theo erator told me
you had beent_rying to telephone all day. I cannot understand this.
First[,]did you wirte me and say that you were going to telephone[?] I
did not receive any letter about it. Secondly I was in the ap[a]rtement
until eleven thirty that morning writing to you and then went to
the beach to return at 1:30for lu[N]ch. At two thirty we went out in th
car to the top of Tantulus and sat there looking at the sea and
mountains until quarter of four and then returned to the apartment
as I have said. I do not see how the operator could have missed me
as she said she had been trying all day and certainly I was there the
gr[e]atest part of the day. Your vlice w s very clear and except for the
times the operator cut us off I coud he r you perfectly. I have enver
known 9 minuts to pass so quickly. I was talking as if you were
sitting next to me and we were saying what we had done after being
seper ted for an hourx instead of three months[,]when suddenly she
was nine minutes and I re alized that we should have been speaking as
fast as those men in the radio who tell you everyithing that has
happened in the world since breakfast in four minutes.
Last night welistened to "Information Please" It[WA]s very 
funnny because everything out here is transcribed and the records are
received[A]bout three weeks after the recording. Hence you will hear so
some question about whether we will try andland troops in Africa,
and then a long argument will take place over it, when we know today
that troopsare already there.
[End Page 3]
4
We were told today that we were to move our o[FF]ice to another part of
this building. I could not believe my ears. Here we had had telephones
insta[L]led special lights, etc. and now they have decided to move us.
The building isa wharehouse andtherefor to make an office out of it
is a very costly procedure because you haveto drill into concrete
to lead in your wires etc. But that isthe life. As soon as you are
in one office they move you into another, at least it keepsus busy
and after the war we will be expert packers. Morris and I can do
the administrative end while you , Rose and Jeep can do the actual
moving. However I am not taking it to ser ously as I find that an order
given one evening is usu aly co untermanded the next morning and that
if you put the most urgent papers in your basketfor a a few hours you
will find that all specifications have beeen d anged andthat it is no[t]
longer urgent, and that you do not have to do anything about it.
The man with the drill hasleft our hall and his place is
[N]ow taken by two wonderful men who peer down the elevator shaft and shout
to a third man that they have hanging on the end of a rope. Ocassionaly
they forget about him and he apparently falls because there is a loud
thump and much cursing comes up the shaft. Then the two in our
office grab hold of the rope and pull a few times and life goes on as
before. Also the stream of men comming ot o r desks asing about
hammers, chains, spark lugs and radio tubes is increasing daily.
The sign intelligence center on the door apparently l res them in with
the idea that al last th y will be told where to go.
Goodhye sweetheart. I will now be able to write you
regularly again until fat face falls ill again. With all my love.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 4]
